title: AI Founders Venture into Venture Capital
description: In this episode, we dive into the unique trend of AI startup founders launching their own venture funds to fuel the next generation of AI-driven businesses.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Hello and welcome to another episode of 'Life is Artificial,' where we explore the cutting edge of technology, innovation, and what the future could look like.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Today, we're talking about a trend that’s really gaining momentum among the pioneers of artificial intelligence. We're seeing AI founders—those who have built successful AI-driven startups—transition into venture capital, starting their own funds to invest in the next wave of AI technologies. It's a fascinating shift in the tech landscape, and it shows us how the AI industry is evolving in ways that are both entrepreneurial and transformative.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: This episode is based on a report from The Information titled 'Why AI Founders Are Starting Their Own Venture Funds,' which examines how these founders, with their deep technical knowledge and industry connections, are managing to secure capital even as first-time fund managers. You can read the full article at theinformation.com.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: So why are AI founders turning to venture capital? Traditionally, raising capital as a new fund manager has been tough. In fact, it’s reportedly the hardest it’s been in over a decade for first-time fund managers. But founders of AI startups seem to be an exception—they’re having success with investors because they bring something unique to the table.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: One notable example is Jeff Arnold, the co-founder of Pilot, an AI-powered accounting firm, and a former operations leader at OpenAI. Arnold and Paul Jun, Pilot’s CFO, recently left the company to start Depth Capital Ventures, a new VC fund targeting AI and enterprise software startups. This fund, according to The Information, has already secured backing from Bain Capital Ventures, and they’re aiming to raise $70 million to invest in pre-seed and seed-stage companies in the AI space.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Then there’s Pebblebed, another venture firm with AI origins. This fund was co-founded by Keith Adams, a former engineer at Meta and technical leader at Slack, along with Pamela Vagata, an early OpenAI team member and former tech lead for Stripe’s AI initiatives. They recently closed their second fund, raising $125 million to back emerging tech companies.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: But what’s even more interesting is that some of these AI founders are holding onto their operational roles at their companies. For example, the co-founders of Octane AI, Ben Parr and Matt Schlicht, launched a venture fund called Theory Forge, targeting early-stage AI companies. And while they’re raising millions for this fund, they’re also still running Octane AI, a profitable company that focuses on AI-driven quizzes for personalized marketing.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: This dual role of being both founder and investor is a shift from what was traditionally accepted in venture capital. It used to be frowned upon; investors worried that taking on side ventures would distract founders from scaling their startups. But today, this has become more accepted, thanks in part to high-profile tech leaders like Sam Altman of OpenAI and Elon Musk, who juggle multiple roles. Investors see these founders as highly connected and technically skilled, which brings in valuable deal flow and insights.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Another AI founder-turned-investor is Richard Socher, who founded You.com, an AI-powered search engine. He started AIX Ventures in 2021 to back AI startups and raised a second fund of $202 million this year, even while securing a $50 million Series B for You.com. Socher manages both roles strategically by having a partner handle AIX's day-to-day operations, freeing him to focus on sourcing deals and hosting events for founders.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: What’s clear is that these founders are leveraging their deep networks and experience in AI to stand out from other fund managers. Caroline Toch Docal, a leader at Bain Capital Ventures, noted that early-stage funds are more crowded than ever, yet these AI founders are finding success because of their unique backgrounds and the high investor interest in artificial intelligence.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: To wrap up, it’s interesting to consider how this trend might shape the future of venture capital and the AI ecosystem. With founder-led funds on the rise, we might see faster innovation as these technically savvy investors back startups that align closely with their expertise. They’re not just investors—they’re insiders, actively building and shaping the field of AI. Their dual roles may even lead to new, unanticipated synergies between the companies they lead and the startups they support.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: So, what do you think? Are these founder-investors onto something big, or is this trend more hype than substance? Could this be the dawn of a new era in venture capital, where industry insiders directly drive innovation from both the operating and investing sides? Let us know your thoughts!

script.speaker: Host
script.text: That’s all for today’s episode. Thanks for tuning in to 'Life is Artificial.' If you enjoyed this episode, consider subscribing and sharing it with your friends. And don’t forget to check out the original article on The Information titled 'Why AI Founders Are Starting Their Own Venture Funds' for more insights. Until next time, stay curious!
